awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Core Support for Future Earth International Global Change Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the US Secretariat of Future Earth. Future Earth harnesses the insights and capacity of the global scientific community to address global problems, like a warming and increasingly unstable climate, and a rapid loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services. The Future Earth effort is based on the recognition that modern global change challenges require coordinated research efforts bringing together the world's best researchers in the natural, social, behavioral, and engineering sciences, and connecting these researchers with the needs and capacities embedded within a wide range of stakeholder institutions and communities. The Secretariat leads and co-leads core functions that include research enabling, networks and capacity, information technology, and communications. In addition, the US Global Hub leads the evolution and growth of Future Earth’s global efforts and directs many of Future Earth’s core global initiatives, including a flagship capacity building program, communications products, and collaborative data-platforms.

Future Earth provides a critical service to the science community by advancing global change science in the US and around the world, and by supporting the full range of research modalities from fundamental disciplinary research to transdisciplinary research. By connecting research across geography and discipline, the project supports the emergence of novel, integrative scientific ideas. By elevating the spread and impact of scientific results and connecting these results with constituencies in business, government, and civil society, Future Earth’s work supports decision making around the world. It also connects US researchers with a vast and rapidly growing network of leading international scholars in global change research and provides direct access to new knowledge and initiatives. This work includes a broad range of communication capacities in the US and around the world, like the establishment of the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress, the first global convening that brings the global change research and innovation communities together, on an annual basis. The Future Earth US Global Hub has also established partnerships to build and diversify the next generation of global change researchers through an internship program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future Earth brought together researchers, policymakers, and other stakeholders to generate knowledge and promote solutions for a sustainable earth. The US Hub (including University of Colorado Boulder, George Mason University, and the NGO Future Earth) led the establishment of various new initiatives, including new funding for projects focused on global change research and sustainability. Future Earth coordinated global research networks around the globe, established a new portal for members to join and interact, and supported the review of the existing programs and a new governance. Through interdisciplinary research and collaboration, Future Earth helped improve our understanding of issues related to Earth system sciences, biodiversity, and global change research, their interconnectedness, and their impacts on social, economic, and ecological systems. Future Earth aimed to bridge the gap between scientific research and policy formulation by engaging with policymakers. It provided evidence-based insights and recommendations to inform decision-making processes at local, national, and international levels for more effective policies and strategies for sustainable development.

Future Earth fostered collaboration and networking among researchers, institutions, and stakeholders from various sectors and regions. Some of these collaborations led to new funding opportunities in support of research. The new member portal that launched the last year created a platform for sharing knowledge, expertise, and best practices, it facilitated cross-disciplinary and international cooperation. This accelerated the development and uptake of sustainable solutions and promoted the exchange of innovative ideas.

Future Earth recognized the importance of engaging with society and ensuring that research and solutions were relevant and accessible to diverse stakeholders. Throughout the grant we engaged in promoting public awareness, participation, and dialogue, increasing societal understanding of sustainability issues and fostering a sense of responsibility. This engagement was meant to lead to more inclusive decision-making processes and the adoption of sustainable practices at individual and community levels. One of the ways of increasing the engagement with a wide audience included the major product Anthropocene magazine that strove to increase public awareness about environmental challenges such as climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and other anthropogenic impacts. 

Future Earth also built and mobilized capacity around the globe to ensure diversity and inclusion of voices from around the world. Future Earth emphasized the importance of capacity building and education to empower researchers and stakeholders to tackle sustainability challenges effectively. Through training programs (such as Earth Leadership and Summer Sustainability Fellows), workshops, and educational initiatives (such as curriculum impact grants), it supported the development of skills, knowledge, and competencies needed to address the challenges of sustainability.
